supporting_sources.title: Tracking COVID-19 with wastewater | Nature Biotechnology
supporting_sources.content: The article from Nature Biotechnology, published on September 21, 2020, discusses the potential of using wastewater surveillance to track the spread of COVID-19, offering a complementary method to traditional epidemiological indicators. Researchers, including David A. Larsen and Krista R. Wigginton, highlight the limitations of current COVID-19 tracking methods, such as diagnostic testing and hospitalization data, which can be biased and delayed. The study by Peccia et al. in New Haven, Connecticut, demonstrated that concentrations of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in sewage sludge correlated with COVID-19 cases and hospital admissions, suggesting that wastewater data could provide near-real-time insights into community transmission. This method, which has been effective in monitoring other viral diseases like polio, is cost-effective and less invasive, capturing data from individuals who may not have access to healthcare. The study found that SARS-CoV-2 RNA concentrations in sludge ranged from 1.7 × 10³ to 4.6 × 10⁵ copies per milliliter, and the data provided early warning of epidemiological trends when accounting for delays in diagnostic testing. Despite challenges in directly correlating viral RNA concentrations to disease prevalence due to biological and infrastructural variability, wastewater surveillance could enhance public health responses, especially in areas with testing delays. The article calls for further research to refine this approach and integrate it into a broader surveillance network, potentially aiding in the timely deployment of interventions and vaccines.

supporting_sources.title: Presence of SARS-Coronavirus-2 in sewage - medRxiv
supporting_sources.content: The study investigates the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in sewage during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, highlighting its potential as a surveillance tool. Researchers collected sewage samples from wastewater treatment plants (WWTP) in seven cities and an airport, testing them using RT-PCR for fragments of the virus's nucleocapsid and envelope protein genes. Initial samples from February 6, 2020, showed no virus presence, but by March 5, the N1 fragment was detected in five sites, and by March 15/16, N1 was found in six sites, with N3 and E fragments detected in five and four sites, respectively. This detection aligns with the emergence of COVID-19 cases in the Netherlands, suggesting that sewage surveillance could sensitively monitor virus circulation, even at low prevalence levels. The study emphasizes the importance of sewage surveillance as a complementary tool to clinical surveillance, potentially serving as an early warning system for COVID-19 outbreaks. The research was supported by KWR Water Research Institute and involved collaboration with local water authorities and WWTP operators.

supporting_sources.title: Presence of SARS-Coronavirus-2 in sewage - medRxiv
supporting_sources.content: The study investigates the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in sewage during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic in the Netherlands, highlighting its potential as a surveillance tool. Researchers collected sewage samples from seven cities and an airport, analyzing them using RT-PCR to detect fragments of the nucleocapsid protein gene (N1-3) and the envelope protein gene (E). Initially, no SARS-CoV-2 was found in samples from February 6, prior to the first reported case in the country on February 27. However, by March 5, the N1 fragment was detected in sewage from five sites, and by March 15/16, the N1 fragment was found in six sites, with the N3 and E fragments detected in five and four sites, respectively. This marks the first report of SARS-CoV-2 detection in sewage, suggesting that sewage surveillance could effectively monitor virus circulation even at low prevalence levels. The research was funded by KWR Water Research Institute, with no external funding, and adhered to all ethical guidelines and reporting standards.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus: occurrence, surveillance, and persistence in wastewater
supporting_sources.content: The article "Coronavirus: occurrence, surveillance, and persistence in wastewater," published in Environmental Monitoring and Assessment, explores the role of wastewater in monitoring the spread of COVID-19. The study highlights the importance of understanding the behavior of the coronavirus in the environment to develop effective control measures. It discusses the detection of low concentrations of coronavirus and its nucleic acids in municipal wastewater, which can serve as an early warning system for outbreaks and help identify asymptomatic carriers. The review focuses on four key areas: the occurrence of coronavirus in wastewater, wastewater-based epidemiological surveillance, tools for detecting coronaviruses in sewage, and the persistence of coronaviruses in wastewater. Various methods, including RT-qPCR and metagenomics, are used to detect viral RNA in wastewater, providing insights into the prevalence and spread of the virus in communities. The study emphasizes the potential of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) as a tool for early detection and monitoring of COVID-19 and other viral outbreaks, highlighting its cost-effectiveness and ability to provide real-time data on community health. The persistence of coronaviruses in wastewater is influenced by factors such as temperature and organic matter, with the virus showing rapid inactivation in these environments. The article concludes that while coronaviruses are not a major problem for water industries due to their low concentrations and susceptibility to degradation, their presence in wastewater can serve as a valuable biomarker for epidemiological surveillance.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) outbreak: some serious
supporting_sources.content: The article published in npj Clean Water on July 3, 2020, explores the potential consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic on urban and rural water cycles, particularly focusing on the risk of transmission through water contaminated with SARS-CoV-2. The study highlights the virus's high transmission rate and the lack of treatment options at the time, emphasizing the possibility of faecal-oral transmission. It notes that while conventional sewage treatment methods with disinfection can eradicate the virus, densely populated countries like India, with limited sewage treatment facilities, face a high risk of contamination. The virus can survive for several days in untreated sewage, posing a significant threat to the 1.8 billion people worldwide who use faecal-contaminated water sources. The study underscores the importance of preventing water pollution at collection, distribution, and consumption points and implementing WHO recommendations for plumbing and ventilation systems to curb the spread of COVID-19. It also discusses the potential for wastewater-based epidemiology as an early warning system and the need for proper wastewater treatment to prevent community transmission. The article concludes that while conventional tertiary wastewater treatment systems are expected to be effective, the high percentage of untreated sewage in countries like India necessitates stringent measures to prevent water contamination and control the outbreak.

supporting_sources.title: Sewage could provide early warning of COVID-19 outbreaks
supporting_sources.content: The article from Medical News Today discusses the potential of using wastewater to provide early warnings of COVID-19 outbreaks. This approach, known as wastewater-based epidemiology, has been proposed by scientists in the U.K. and China after the SARS-CoV-2 virus was detected in stool samples of the first confirmed COVID-19 case in the U.S. Wastewater analysis is already used in the U.S. and Europe to monitor illicit drug use and other health indicators. Dr. Zhugen Yang and his team at Cranfield University and the Chinese Academy of Sciences have developed a paper-based test that could detect the virus in wastewater, offering a cost-effective and rapid alternative to traditional lab tests. This test, which builds on Yang's previous work on malaria detection, could be crucial for identifying asymptomatic carriers and implementing early quarantine measures. The paper device, which costs less than 50 cents, uses origami-like folds to process samples and can deliver results in about 50 minutes. It is compact, easy to use, and can be safely disposed of by incineration. The development of this test is supported by the Natural Environment Research Council and the Royal Academy of Engineering in the U.K., with an estimated timeline of up to a year for full development and validation.

supporting_sources.title: Evidence suggests COVID-19 is not transmitted through wastewater
supporting_sources.content: The report by Dr. Mark Sobsey from the UNC Gillings School of Global Public Health addresses concerns about the potential transmission of COVID-19 through wastewater. Despite the presence of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater, which indicates community spread, Sobsey's review, published in the Journal of Water & Health, finds no evidence that the virus in fecal waste is infectious or capable of spreading. The virus is primarily transmitted through aerosols and respiratory droplets, and while infected individuals shed viral particles in fecal waste, Sobsey's analysis of scientific literature and studies shows no documented cases of COVID-19 transmission through water or wastewater. As a retired Kenan Distinguished Professor and advisor for WHO and CDC, Sobsey's expertise has been crucial in guiding public health experts on the risks of COVID-19 exposure through water. His findings emphasize that there is no epidemiological evidence linking water and wastewater to human cases or outbreaks of COVID-19, thus negating the need for concern over transmission through these sources.

supporting_sources.title: Scientists Have a New Tool for Tracking COVID-19 Variants - Time
supporting_sources.content: The article by Alice Park discusses a novel approach developed by scientists for tracking COVID-19 variants through wastewater analysis, providing a more comprehensive and early detection method compared to traditional testing. During the pandemic, wastewater has been a valuable tool for identifying peaks in infections before they are evident in healthcare settings. Researchers, led by Rob Knight at the University of California, San Diego, have enhanced this method to not only detect the presence of SARS-CoV-2 but also identify specific variants by analyzing genetic signatures in wastewater samples. This approach was tested on nearly 20,000 samples from the UC San Diego campus, allowing the team to detect infection trends up to 14 days before they were confirmed by clinical tests. The system also enabled the identification of a broader range of virus strains than those detected through PCR tests, offering a more accurate picture of variant diversity. The study, which collected data from November 2020 to February 2022, successfully tracked the emergence and prevalence of variants like Alpha, Delta, and Omicron, demonstrating the rapid replacement of Delta by Omicron. The findings underscore the potential of wastewater surveillance as an unbiased, community-wide indicator of infection dynamics, offering public health officials a powerful tool to anticipate and respond to outbreaks. The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has recognized this potential, launching a National Wastewater Surveillance Program to monitor virus loads across the country. This method addresses biases inherent in clinical testing and provides a leading indicator of infection trends, crucial for managing the ongoing evolution of SARS-CoV-2.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Monitoring in Maricopa County
supporting_sources.content: The Maricopa County Department of Public Health (MCDPH) plays a pivotal role in Arizona's wastewater surveillance program, collaborating with the Arizona Department of Health Services (ADHS), city agencies, utilities, and laboratories as part of the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS) initiated by the CDC in 2020. This program monitors wastewater for pathogens like SARS-CoV-2, influenza A & B, influenza A(H5), and RSV A & B, alongside illicit substances, to enhance public health responses. Wastewater-based epidemiology offers a comprehensive view of community health by analyzing genetic material from pathogens and chemical targets in sewage, providing insights into disease prevalence and substance use without relying on healthcare-seeking behaviors. This method can detect disease spread, such as COVID-19, days before clinical data, offering a proactive approach to public health. However, challenges include data interpretation and comparison across different sewersheds due to variability in sampling methods and community characteristics. In Maricopa County, cities like Phoenix, Tempe, and Surprise participate in this surveillance, with Tempe also monitoring additional pathogens and drugs. The program's data, collected bi-weekly, is crucial for understanding community health trends and informing timely interventions. Despite its benefits, wastewater monitoring faces limitations, such as the inability to pinpoint pathogen origins within a community and the complexity of comparing data across regions. Efforts continue to refine these methods to improve accuracy and utility in public health decision-making.

supporting_sources.title: Why sewage may hold the key to tracking diseases far beyond
supporting_sources.content: The article by Betsy Ladyzhets in Science News explores the burgeoning field of wastewater surveillance as a tool for tracking public health threats beyond COVID-19. Initially a niche area focused on detecting drugs and mapping microbial ecosystems, wastewater surveillance gained prominence during the COVID-19 pandemic by successfully tracking the spread of the virus and its variants. This success has led to a rapid expansion of the field, with hundreds of wastewater treatment plants in the U.S. and globally participating in monitoring programs like the National Wastewater Surveillance System (NWSS). Researchers are now exploring the potential of this method to track a variety of pathogens, including seasonal diseases like the flu, emerging threats like bird flu and mpox, and drug-resistant pathogens such as Candida auris. Despite its promise, the field faces challenges, including the need for standardized protocols and sustained funding, as well as the difficulty of translating environmental data into actionable public health policies. The article highlights the potential of wastewater surveillance to provide early warnings of disease outbreaks, but emphasizes the need for further research and collaboration among scientists, health officials, and policymakers to fully realize its benefits.

supporting_sources.title: New Article in The Conversation: COVID-19 clues in a community's
supporting_sources.content: The article from the University of Notre Dame's GERM Lab, published in The Conversation and authored by Katherine Crank, explores the potential of monitoring community sewage to detect COVID-19. This method, while gaining recent attention, has historical roots dating back to the 1940s when scientists began examining sewage for pathogens like poliovirus. The process involves detecting fragments of the virus's RNA in wastewater, as approximately two-thirds of individuals infected with SARS-CoV-2 excrete the virus in their stool. The approach typically requires concentrating the wastewater sample to enhance the likelihood of detecting viral RNA, which is achieved through techniques like electrostatic interaction to capture the RNA fragments. Although this method provides valuable data, the article notes that it is not yet possible to directly correlate the amount of viral RNA in wastewater to the exact number of infected individuals in a community. This innovative surveillance strategy offers a promising tool for public health monitoring, despite the current limitations in quantifying community infection rates directly from wastewater analysis.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Epidemiology & Surveillance Program | Texas DSHS
supporting_sources.content: The Texas Department of State Health Services (DSHS) provides an overview of its Wastewater Epidemiology & Surveillance Program, which is part of the Environmental Epidemiology & Disease Registries Section. This program utilizes wastewater surveillance to monitor pathogens within communities, offering a non-invasive, timely, and cost-effective method to track infectious disease trends. Wastewater, which includes household and non-household water, is systematically sampled and analyzed to detect genetic material from pathogens, even from asymptomatic individuals. This approach complements traditional public health tools like clinical testing and has been particularly effective during the COVID-19 pandemic for tracking SARS-CoV-2 levels. The data collected can alert public health officials to disease trends earlier than clinical testing, confirm infection rates, and identify pathogen variants of concern, such as the Omicron variant. DSHS collaborates with local health departments and water utilities to collect and interpret this data, which helps shape public health policies and direct resources to areas with high transmission rates. The program invites municipalities interested in participating to contact them for more information.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus Q&As: Member Questions, Wastewater Surveillance
supporting_sources.content: The article discusses the role of wastewater professionals in monitoring the spread of COVID-19 through wastewater surveillance, as highlighted in a series of webinars sponsored by WEST YOST and organized by CASA-CWEA. The webinars address various questions from members regarding the presence and infectivity of the coronavirus in wastewater. According to the CDC and WEF, there is no evidence of viable COVID-19 virus in wastewater systems, and the virus is unlikely to survive the disinfection processes used in water treatment. The CDC clarifies that while RNA from the virus is detectable in wastewater and feces, this does not indicate infectivity. The article also covers safety recommendations for wastewater workers, emphasizing the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) and hygiene practices to prevent infection. Additionally, the CDC is evaluating the potential of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) to estimate community infection levels, though widespread monitoring is not currently recommended. The article also touches on the challenges of detecting the virus in wastewater, the potential impact of pre-chlorination, and the need for rapid testing results to inform public health actions. The discussion includes the use of PCR for virus detection, the importance of sample concentration, and the potential for using robots in sample collection. The article concludes with insights into the costs and logistics of wastewater testing, the use of UV light for disinfection, and the testing protocols for wastewater employees.

supporting_sources.title: Califor​nia Wastewater Surveillance Network Dashboard - CDPH
supporting_sources.content: The California Department of Public Health (CDPH) has developed a new Wastewater Surveillance Dashboard to monitor SARS-CoV-2 levels in wastewater across California. This initiative, part of the California Wastewater Surveillance Network (CA WWS Network), involves collaboration between CDPH, wastewater utilities, academic institutions, and laboratories. The dashboard provides a visual representation of SARS-CoV-2 RNA concentrations in wastewater, with data updated daily from Monday to Friday. Wastewater samples are typically collected on Sundays, Mondays, and Wednesdays, with a turnaround time of 3-6 days for results to appear on the dashboard. The data is presented as either raw or normalized concentrations, with normalization using the Pepper Mild Mottle virus (PMMoV) as a human fecal indicator, which has shown improved correlation with COVID-19 case incidence rates. The dashboard includes maps of sewersheds, showing where samples are collected, and graphs displaying average concentrations and 10-day rolling averages to highlight trends. The CDPH emphasizes that wastewater surveillance is an evolving field, and the data should be interpreted with caution. The full dataset is available on the California Open Data Portal, and further inquiries can be directed to the CDPH Cal-SuWers Team.

supporting_sources.title: An interpretative review of the wastewater-based surveillance of the
supporting_sources.content: The article from Frontiers in Microbiology provides an in-depth review of wastewater-based epidemiology (WBE) as a tool for monitoring the presence and spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. Historically used since the 1940s for tracking diseases like polio and hepatitis, WBE has gained prominence for its potential in early detection of SARS-CoV-2 at the community level. The review compiles data from 68 studies across 26 countries, highlighting various methods for detecting the virus in wastewater, including serological, biosensor, PCR, and next-generation sequencing techniques. The presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in wastewater, which results from viral shedding in human feces, saliva, and other secretions, can serve as an early warning system, potentially identifying outbreaks before clinical cases are reported. The article emphasizes the need for continued development of sensitive, cost-effective surveillance strategies, especially in light of emerging variants like JN.1. Despite the promise of WBE, challenges remain, such as correlating viral load in wastewater with actual infection rates and understanding the virus's viability in these environments. The review underscores the importance of WBE in public health planning and pandemic preparedness, advocating for its integration into long-term surveillance strategies to mitigate the impacts of current and future viral outbreaks.

supporting_sources.title: Waste water flowing in communities can reveal presence of COVID-19
supporting_sources.content: The article from Healthwise by Punch Nigeria Limited covers a range of health-related topics, highlighting significant issues and developments. It begins with the Guild of Medical Directors criticizing the imposition of parking fees on private hospitals in Lagos, arguing that it adds unnecessary financial burdens. In another report, experts advocate for data-driven strategies to address maternal mortality and stillbirths in Nigeria, emphasizing the importance of accurate data in formulating effective health policies. The Medical Laboratory Science Council of Nigeria recently inducted 45 graduates from the University of Lagos, marking a significant step in bolstering the country's healthcare workforce. Meanwhile, a severe Lassa fever outbreak in Nigeria has resulted in 80 deaths within a week, prompting calls for improved hygiene practices to curb the spread. Additionally, experts in sexual health reassure that penis size does not significantly impact sexual performance or fertility. In a separate study, scientists are exploring wastewater analysis as a method to detect COVID-19 presence in communities, offering a non-invasive early-warning system for potential outbreaks. This approach, already yielding results in countries like the Netherlands, the U.S., and Sweden, could provide a more comprehensive understanding of virus spread than individual testing, as it accounts for asymptomatic cases.

supporting_sources.title: MDE COVID-19 Update - Maryland Department of the Environment
supporting_sources.content: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) provides an update on various initiatives and regulatory adjustments in response to the COVID-19 pandemic. The department highlights the Sewer Sentinel Initiative and the availability of related maps, as well as the careful exercise of enforcement discretion during this period. A significant focus is on the status of water, wastewater, and industrial wastewater operator certifications. Under the Governor's Executive Order, certifications that expired on or after April 1, 2020, have been administratively renewed and remain active until June 30, 2021, with late fees resuming on July 1, 2021. Certifications that expired between January 1, 2020, and March 1, 2020, were within a 90-day grace period and are now considered inactive, with reinstatement resuming on July 1, 2021. Certifications that expired before December 31, 2019, are inactive, and those beyond the two-year reinstatement period cannot be renewed. The MDE also provides guidance on electronically accepted permit applications and Public Information Act requests, directing inquiries to the Board of Waterworks and Waste Systems Operators via email. The department maintains communication through various social media channels.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Testing - Mathematica
supporting_sources.content: The article from Mathematica highlights the organization's multifaceted approach to leveraging data and evidence-based strategies to address public health challenges, with a particular focus on wastewater testing. Wastewater monitoring is presented as a cost-effective and rapid method for detecting viral particles, chemicals, and pathogens, providing public officials with timely insights into community health trends. This method is especially valuable for tracking COVID-19 infections, offering early warnings of outbreaks and helping to manage public health responses. The article details how Mathematica collaborates with municipalities and community partners to scale these efforts, using statistical analysis and decision support tools to translate lab results into actionable insights. Additionally, the article discusses the application of wastewater data in confronting the opioid epidemic, highlighting its potential in emerging drug detection and overdose prediction. Mathematica's work extends globally, emphasizing the need for coordinated wastewater monitoring practices and addressing the costs associated with such efforts in low- and middle-income countries. The organization also offers a range of services, including enhanced surveillance, policy guidance, and mitigation strategies, to support public health officials in making informed decisions.

supporting_sources.title: Monitoring SARS-CoV-2 variants in wastewater of Dhaka City
supporting_sources.content: The study published in "Human Genomics" on July 7, 2023, investigates the dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 variants in the wastewater of Dhaka City, Bangladesh, as a complementary approach to public health surveillance. Given the challenges of limited wastewater treatment in Dhaka, the study aimed to explore the genetic diversity of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater and its correlation with clinical data. Researchers collected 504 wastewater samples from various sites, including community drains, hospital septic tanks, and pumping stations, between September 2020 and May 2021. Using RT-qPCR, 36.7% of these samples tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA, with a median concentration of 5.2 log10 N gene copies per liter. Whole genome sequencing of selected samples revealed the presence of multiple clades and lineages, including the Delta variant, which was detected in wastewater months before its identification in clinical samples. This finding underscores the potential of wastewater surveillance in early detection and monitoring of SARS-CoV-2 variants, providing valuable insights for public health strategies. The study highlights the importance of environmental surveillance in densely populated areas with inadequate sanitation infrastructure, offering a cost-effective method for tracking viral spread and informing public health responses.

supporting_sources.title: Houston Wastewater Epidemiology
supporting_sources.content: The article details the Houston Wastewater Epidemiology initiative, a collaborative effort between the Houston Health Department, Rice University, and Houston Public Works, aimed at monitoring wastewater to detect pathogens responsible for communicable diseases such as COVID-19, influenza, and RSV. This program involves weekly sampling from various wastewater sites across Houston, with samples analyzed by independent labs to identify the presence of these pathogens. The data serves as an early warning system, allowing health officials to advise the public on preventive measures. A significant component of this initiative is the pilot program launched in December 2020 with the Houston Independent School District, which monitors wastewater from school bathrooms to detect germs. Alerts are sent to the community via text or email when pathogens are detected, providing guidance on protective actions, such as vaccination. The article reassures that Houston's drinking water remains safe, as it is supplied through a separate system. Additionally, it provides information on COVID-19, flu, and RSV, including symptoms, transmission, and preventive measures, emphasizing the importance of vaccination and hygiene practices. The article also offers resources for further information and access to health services, including immunizations and testing.

supporting_sources.title: Wastewater Covid-19 Tracking - MWRA
supporting_sources.content: The Massachusetts Water Resources Authority (MWRA) is conducting a pilot study at the Deer Island Treatment Plant to track COVID-19 infection indicators through wastewater analysis. This initiative involves daily sample analysis by Biobot Analytics, a company specializing in wastewater epidemiology. Results are typically posted 2-3 working days after collection, with the latest data available up to February 18, 2025. A recent calibration update by Biobot Analytics has slightly adjusted individual data points from the past six months, though overall trends remain unchanged. The data, represented in graphs with error bars indicating variability, is divided into the North and South Systems, marked by green and orange dots, respectively. The study also includes variant screening results and is complemented by additional disease target testing through the WastewaterSCAN program. For further context, the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) provide additional information on SARS-CoV-2 genetic material in wastewater. The MWRA encourages the public to refer to the Massachusetts Department of Public Health for current COVID-19 case information in their communities.

supporting_sources.title: Infectious SARS-CoV-2 in Feces of Patient with Severe COVID-19
supporting_sources.content: The study, published in August 2020, investigates the presence of infectious SARS-CoV-2 in the feces of a patient with severe COVID-19, highlighting the potential for fecal-oral or fecal-respiratory transmission. Conducted in China, the research involved a 78-year-old patient who had traveled to Wuhan and was admitted with COVID-19 symptoms. Despite treatment, the patient's condition worsened, and he eventually died. Researchers collected fecal samples, which tested positive for viral RNA through quantitative reverse transcription PCR (qRT-PCR). The study successfully isolated infectious virus from the feces, confirmed by cytopathic effects in Vero E6 cells and sequencing that revealed five nucleotide substitutions compared to the original Wuhan strain. The viral load in feces was higher than in respiratory specimens, although only RNA fragments were detected in later samples. Among 28 patients tested, 12 showed viral RNA in feces, with successful virus isolation in 2 cases. The findings underscore the need for precautions to prevent potential transmission from feces, especially in hospital settings. The study was supported by several Chinese research grants and emphasizes the importance of considering fecal transmission routes in managing COVID-19.

supporting_sources.title: Potential intestinal infection and faecal–oral transmission of SARS
supporting_sources.content: The article from Nature Reviews Gastroenterology & Hepatology, published on February 15, 2021, explores the potential for intestinal infection and fecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. The study highlights that while SARS-CoV-2 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets, a significant number of COVID-19 patients exhibit gastrointestinal symptoms, and nearly half have detectable viral RNA in their feces. The virus is known to alter intestinal microbiota, correlating with inflammatory responses. Evidence from in vitro and in vivo studies supports the possibility of intestinal infection, with the virus binding to ACE2 receptors, which are highly expressed in the intestine. The study also discusses the potential for fecal-oral transmission, noting that viral RNA has been detected in sewage and on surfaces in bathrooms, although direct evidence of transmission via this route is still lacking. The article calls for further research to understand the mechanisms of intestinal infection, its impact on the immune response, and the potential for fecal-oral transmission, which could have significant implications for managing the COVID-19 pandemic.

supporting_sources.title: SARS-CoV-2 and the Role of Orofecal Transmission: Evidence Brief
supporting_sources.content: The Centre for Evidence-Based Medicine's evidence brief, published on July 16, 2020, explores the potential role of orofecal transmission in the spread of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. The brief is part of an open evidence review analyzing the transmission dynamics of COVID-19. The review includes 36 studies on orofecal transmission and additional mechanistic and observational evidence from 22 studies, highlighting that SARS-CoV-2 can infect and be shed from the human gastrointestinal tract. Approximately 12% of COVID-19 patients report gastrointestinal symptoms, and viral RNA has been detected in the stool of up to 41% of patients. The evidence suggests that fecal shedding can persist longer than respiratory shedding, with some studies indicating fecal shedding up to 47 days post-symptom onset. Although most studies have not isolated live virus from fecal samples, a few have successfully done so, suggesting the potential for orofecal transmission. The brief recommends routine surveillance of food, wastewater, and effluent, along with strict personal hygiene and disinfection measures, to mitigate this transmission route. Further research is encouraged to explore the viability and pathogenicity of fecal isolates and to conduct case-control studies during outbreak investigations. The evidence brief underscores the importance of understanding all possible transmission routes to inform public health policies and prevent the spread of COVID-19.

supporting_sources.title: Excretion and viability of SARS-CoV-2 in feces and its association
supporting_sources.content: The study published in Scientific Reports on May 5, 2022, investigates the excretion and viability of SARS-CoV-2 in feces and its potential association with the clinical outcomes of COVID-19. Conducted as a prospective multicenter cohort study, it involved 62 adult COVID-19 patients admitted to four hospitals in Spain between March 2020 and February 2021. The researchers collected 79 stool samples from these patients to detect SARS-CoV-2 RNA and assess the virus's replicative capacity. They found that 43.5% of the patients had detectable SARS-CoV-2 RNA in their stool samples. However, no replicative virus was observed, as confirmed by the absence of cytopathic effects in cell cultures and RT-PCR tests. The study concluded that fecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is highly unlikely, as the virus's replicative capacity in stool samples is null or very limited. Additionally, the presence of SARS-CoV-2 RNA in feces was not associated with gastrointestinal symptoms or unfavorable clinical outcomes, such as ICU admission or death. The findings suggest that while SARS-CoV-2 RNA can be detected in feces, it does not contribute significantly to the transmission of the virus.

supporting_sources.title: Transmission of SARS-CoV-2: implications for infection prevention
supporting_sources.content: The World Health Organization (WHO) released a scientific brief updating the understanding of SARS-CoV-2 transmission, emphasizing its implications for infection prevention and control. The brief, which is not a systematic review, consolidates rapid reviews of peer-reviewed and pre-print studies, and insights from expert discussions. It highlights that SARS-CoV-2 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets and close contact, with potential for airborne transmission during aerosol-generating medical procedures. The brief also explores the possibility of aerosol transmission in crowded indoor spaces with poor ventilation, though more research is needed to confirm this. Fomite transmission, through contaminated surfaces, is considered likely, although direct evidence is lacking. The document underscores the importance of understanding when infected individuals are most contagious, noting that viral RNA can be detected 1-3 days before symptom onset, with peak viral loads around the time symptoms appear. Asymptomatic and pre-symptomatic individuals can also transmit the virus, but the extent remains unclear. The WHO recommends a comprehensive set of measures to prevent transmission, including rapid identification and isolation of cases, quarantine of contacts, use of masks in public settings, and adherence to hygiene and distancing protocols. The brief calls for urgent research to better understand transmission dynamics, including the role of asymptomatic carriers and the potential for airborne spread outside healthcare settings.

supporting_sources.title: Feces of people with mild COVID can harbor viral genetic material
supporting_sources.content: The study conducted by researchers at Stanford Medicine reveals that individuals with mild to moderate COVID-19 can continue to shed viral RNA in their feces for up to seven months post-infection. This research, led by Ami Bhatt, MD, PhD, and published in Med, is the first to examine fecal samples from such patients over time, highlighting the potential for the gut to serve as a viral reservoir. The study involved analyzing samples from 113 participants, finding that about half shed viral genetic material within a week of testing positive, 13% continued to do so four months later, and nearly 4% at seven months. This fecal shedding was associated with persistent gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea and abdominal pain. The findings suggest that the immune response to viral proteins in hidden reservoirs, such as the gut, might contribute to long COVID symptoms. The study also raises questions about the accuracy of wastewater surveillance for COVID-19 case counts, given the prolonged shedding of viral RNA. The research was supported by several grants, including those from the National Institutes of Health, and is part of the broader RECOVER Initiative.

supporting_sources.title: Lack of evidence for infectious SARS-CoV-2 in feces and sewage
supporting_sources.content: The article from the European Journal of Clinical Microbiology & Infectious Diseases, published on July 9, 2021, investigates the potential for fecal-oral transmission of SARS-CoV-2 by examining the presence of infectious viral particles in feces and sewage. The study, conducted in Spain, involved analyzing fecal samples from eight COVID-19 patients and wastewater samples from treatment plants in Valencia. Researchers employed a high-speed centrifugation method to concentrate samples while maintaining viral infectivity, followed by RNA extraction and RT-qPCR testing. Despite detecting viral RNA in feces from six out of eight patients, ranging from 8.34 × 10³ to 6.74 × 10⁶ gc/L, and in sewage samples with high viral loads, no infectious viral particles were found in cell culture assays. The study highlights that while SARS-CoV-2 RNA is frequently present in feces, the lack of evidence for infective particles suggests that fecal-oral transmission is not a primary route. The authors emphasize the need for further research, especially with emerging viral variants, and suggest that improved detection methodologies could provide more insights into potential transmission routes.

supporting_sources.title: Modes of transmission of virus causing COVID-19: implications for
supporting_sources.content: The World Health Organization (WHO) released a scientific brief on the modes of transmission of the virus causing COVID-19, updating previous guidance with new evidence as of July 9. The brief clarifies the definitions of respiratory droplets and droplet nuclei based on particle size, emphasizing that COVID-19 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets and contact routes. An analysis of 75,465 cases in China found no evidence of airborne transmission under normal circumstances. However, airborne transmission may occur during specific aerosol-generating medical procedures. The brief also notes the potential for intestinal infection, though faecal-oral transmission has not been reported. Recent studies have detected the virus in aerosols under experimental conditions, but these findings do not necessarily reflect real-world settings. WHO continues to recommend droplet and contact precautions for general care of COVID-19 patients, with airborne precautions reserved for aerosol-generating procedures. These guidelines align with those of other international health organizations. WHO stresses the importance of proper use of personal protective equipment (PPE), hand hygiene, and environmental cleaning, while monitoring emerging evidence to update recommendations as needed.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 infects cells of the intestine
supporting_sources.content: Researchers from the Hubrecht Institute, Erasmus MC University Medical Center Rotterdam, and Maastricht University in the Netherlands have discovered that the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2, responsible for COVID-19, can infect and replicate in intestinal cells. This study, published in the journal Science on May 1, 2020, utilized advanced cell culture models known as human intestinal organoids to simulate the human intestine in vitro. The researchers observed that the virus could enter and multiply within these organoids, which are rich in ACE2 receptors, the entry point for the virus. This finding provides a potential explanation for why approximately one-third of COVID-19 patients experience gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea and why the virus is often found in stool samples, suggesting possible fecal-oral transmission. The study employed electron microscopy to visualize virus particles within and outside the organoid cells and used RNA sequencing to identify the activation of interferon-stimulated genes, which combat viral infections. Interestingly, the virus was able to infect cells with varying levels of ACE2 receptors, indicating potential new avenues for blocking viral entry. The researchers emphasize the need for further investigation into the role of the gastrointestinal tract in virus transmission and suggest that more comprehensive testing, including rectal swabs or stool samples, may be necessary. The study's findings align with other research highlighting gastrointestinal symptoms in COVID-19 patients and underscore the importance of continued research into the differences between lung and intestinal infections by SARS-CoV-2.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) - Symptoms and causes
supporting_sources.content: The Mayo Clinic article provides a comprehensive overview of COVID-19, a disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which emerged in late 2019 and led to a global pandemic in 2020. The virus primarily spreads through airborne droplets from infected individuals, even those who are asymptomatic. While many experience mild symptoms, such as dry cough, fatigue, and loss of taste or smell, the disease can lead to severe complications, particularly in older adults and those with pre-existing health conditions. The article emphasizes the importance of vaccination, detailing the available COVID-19 vaccines in the U.S., including Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Novavax, and their recommended dosages for different age groups. It also highlights preventive measures like good hygiene, mask-wearing, and maintaining physical distance to curb the virus's spread. The article discusses the risk factors for severe illness, including age, underlying health conditions, and lack of vaccination, and outlines potential complications such as acute respiratory distress syndrome and long COVID. The Mayo Clinic underscores the significance of staying informed about COVID-19 through reliable sources and maintaining up-to-date vaccinations to reduce the risk of severe outcomes.

supporting_sources.title: Research reveals how long SARS-CoV-2 survives on surfaces, in
supporting_sources.content: The article from News-Medical, authored by Dr. Liji Thomas, discusses a study published on medRxiv in May 2020, which investigates the stability of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, on various surfaces and in human excreta. The study, now peer-reviewed and published in a scientific journal, reveals that the virus can remain viable for up to seven days on smooth surfaces such as plastic, stainless steel, and glass, and for several hours to days in human feces and urine. Researchers tested the virus's stability on nine different materials and in fecal and urine samples from two adults and a child. The virus's infectious potential, measured by TCID50, showed a significant decline over time, with a two-phase decay observed in urine samples. The study highlights the importance of understanding viral transmission routes, emphasizing the need for stringent hygiene and disinfection practices to curb the spread of COVID-19. The findings extend previous research by demonstrating longer virus viability on surfaces and underscore the necessity of immediate virus plating from samples to maximize yield. The World Health Organization's recommendations on preventing transmission through contaminated surfaces are supported by these findings, which are crucial for informing public health policies.

supporting_sources.title: SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19 | BCM - Baylor College of Medicine
supporting_sources.content: The article from Baylor College of Medicine provides a comprehensive overview of the SARS-CoV-2 virus and the COVID-19 pandemic, detailing the virus's origins, transmission, and impact. SARS-CoV-2, responsible for COVID-19, emerged in Wuhan, China, in late 2019 and rapidly spread globally, leading to a pandemic declared by the WHO in March 2020. The virus, part of the coronavirus family, is notable for its ability to spread even from asymptomatic individuals, primarily through respiratory droplets and aerosols. The article highlights the virus's reproduction rate, R(t), which indicates the spread rate within communities, and discusses the wide range of symptoms, from mild to severe, that COVID-19 can cause. It also addresses the emergence of variants, such as Alpha, Beta, Gamma, and Delta, which have raised concerns due to their increased transmissibility and potential to evade vaccines. The article outlines the development and deployment of vaccines, including those from Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna, and Johnson & Johnson, emphasizing their safety and efficacy. It also discusses ongoing research efforts at Baylor, including vaccine development and monitoring of SARS-CoV-2 in the community through diagnostic testing and wastewater surveillance. The article underscores the importance of achieving herd immunity through vaccination to control the virus's spread and highlights the challenges posed by vaccine hesitancy. Additionally, it touches on the potential for future pandemics and the need for preparedness and scientific collaboration to mitigate their impact.

supporting_sources.title: On the whereabouts of SARS-CoV-2 in the human body - PLOS
supporting_sources.content: The article from PLOS Pathogens presents a systematic review of the distribution of SARS-CoV-2 in the human body, highlighting its broad organotropism and the complex interplay with the host. Researchers from the HIV Cure Research Center at Ghent University conducted a comprehensive literature review, focusing on the presence of viral components in various human tissues and body fluids, and correlating these findings with the expression of the ACE2 receptor, the main entry point for the virus. The study found that SARS-CoV-2 affects multiple organs beyond the respiratory system, including the heart, intestines, brain, kidneys, and male genitals, and is present in body fluids such as mucus, saliva, urine, semen, and breast milk. Despite the widespread detection of viral RNA, the presence of infectious virus was confirmed in only a few cases, particularly in the lungs, stool, and urine. The review also noted that ACE2 expression levels do not always correlate with viral detection, suggesting a more complex mechanism of infection. The findings underscore the need for further research to understand the pathogenesis of COVID-19 and improve diagnostic and treatment strategies. The study was supported by various research grants, and the authors declared no competing interests.

supporting_sources.title: Indoor Air and Coronavirus (COVID-19) | US EPA
supporting_sources.content: The article from an official U.S. government website provides comprehensive information on the transmission of COVID-19 through indoor air, emphasizing the role of airborne particles and droplets in spreading the virus. It explains that individuals infected with COVID-19 can release respiratory fluids containing the SARS-CoV-2 virus into the air through activities like breathing, speaking, and coughing. These particles, which vary in size, can travel beyond six feet and remain airborne for hours, posing a risk of infection even after the infected person has left the room. The article highlights that indoor environments with inadequate ventilation, activities that increase respiratory emissions, prolonged exposure, and crowded spaces elevate the risk of airborne transmission. To mitigate this risk, the article recommends increasing ventilation with outdoor air, using air filtration, and following best practices such as physical distancing, wearing masks, and regular cleaning. It also provides links to resources and guidelines from the CDC and other agencies on improving indoor air quality and preventing the spread of COVID-19. Additionally, it suggests consulting the latest advice from state, local, Tribal, and federal agencies for more detailed guidance.

supporting_sources.title: Infection Control Guidance: SARS-CoV-2 | COVID-19 - CDC
supporting_sources.content: The CDC's updated infection control guidance for SARS-CoV-2, as of May 8, 2023, reflects the evolving landscape of COVID-19 management in healthcare settings, particularly following the end of the federal Public Health Emergency on May 11, 2023. This guidance is part of a broader update to the 2007 Guideline for Isolation Precautions, which is currently under review by the Healthcare Infection Control Practices Advisory Committee (HICPAC). The guidance emphasizes the importance of maintaining high levels of vaccine-induced and infection-induced immunity, alongside the availability of effective treatments and prevention tools. It provides a framework for healthcare facilities to implement infection prevention and control practices, such as universal source control, based on local circumstances and community transmission levels. With the cessation of the Community Transmission metric, facilities are encouraged to identify local metrics to guide the use of source control measures. Key recommendations include staying up-to-date with COVID-19 vaccinations, implementing source control measures like masks and respirators, and optimizing the use of personal protective equipment (PPE) and engineering controls. The guidance also outlines specific infection prevention practices for managing patients with suspected or confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, including the use of Transmission-Based Precautions and criteria for discontinuing these precautions. Additionally, the guidance provides setting-specific considerations for various healthcare environments, such as dialysis facilities and nursing homes, and addresses the use of personal protective equipment by healthcare personnel and visitors. The CDC continues to recommend the use of NIOSH-approved particulate respirators with N95 filters or higher for the care of patients with known or suspected COVID-19, due to their superior fit and filtration capabilities. The guidance is subject to further updates as new information becomes available and as the response to SARS-CoV-2 evolves.

supporting_sources.title: Isolation of 2019-nCoV from a Stool Specimen of a Laboratory
supporting_sources.content: The study conducted by the National Health Commission Key Laboratory for Medical Virology and the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention highlights a significant finding in the transmission routes of the novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV), particularly in Hubei Province, China, where the virus was spreading rapidly as of February 14, 2020, with 51,986 confirmed cases and 1,318 deaths. Researchers isolated a strain of 2019-nCoV from a stool specimen of a laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 patient in a Biosafety Level 3 Laboratory using Vero cells. The patient, who experienced severe pneumonia, was sampled 15 days after symptom onset. The isolated virus showed a 99.98% nucleotide similarity to the first strain isolated in Wuhan, China. Electron microscopy confirmed the presence of viral particles with typical coronavirus morphology. This study reveals that live virus can be present in stool specimens, suggesting a potential fecal-oral transmission route, in addition to the known respiratory and contact transmission. This finding underscores the importance of public health measures to prevent fecal-oral transmission, such as maintaining hygiene, disinfecting surfaces, and ensuring safe food and water practices. The study was supported by the National Key Technology R&D Programs of China, emphasizing its public health significance in controlling the spread of COVID-19.

supporting_sources.title: Coronavirus: How Can We Prevent COVID-19? - WebMD
supporting_sources.content: The article on WebMD, medically reviewed by Dr. Zilpah Sheikh, provides a comprehensive overview of COVID-19 prevention, transmission, and symptom duration. It highlights that while most mild COVID-19 infections resolve within a few weeks, symptoms can persist for months in some cases, particularly in severe infections or among those with compromised immune systems. The article emphasizes the importance of staying up-to-date with vaccinations, practicing good hygiene, and avoiding contact with others when infected to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The World Health Organization reports over 103 million cases in the U.S. since January 2020, with the virus primarily spreading through person-to-person contact via droplets and aerosols. The article notes that individuals can be contagious even before symptoms appear and that asymptomatic spread is common. It also discusses the potential for surface transmission, although this is less common. The CDC recommends preventive measures such as masking, social distancing, and improving indoor ventilation. The article also addresses the risk factors for severe illness, including age, underlying health conditions, and being unvaccinated, and advises those at higher risk to take extra precautions. Additionally, it covers the potential for pets to contract COVID-19 from humans, though transmission from pets to humans is unlikely. The article concludes by stressing the importance of COVID-19 prevention to protect vulnerable populations and reduce the risk of severe illness and hospitalization.

supporting_sources.content: The study published in Frontiers in Molecular Biosciences investigates the presence of the SARS-CoV-2 genome in stool and plasma samples of 191 Iranian COVID-19 patients, aiming to explore potential non-respiratory transmission routes and their correlation with disease severity. Utilizing reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR), researchers analyzed samples from patients admitted to Taleghani and Imam Hossein Educational Hospitals. The study found that 20.51% of plasma samples and 27.03% of stool samples tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 RNA. Despite these findings, no significant correlation was observed between the presence of the virus in these samples and the severity of COVID-19 symptoms. The research highlights the potential for non-respiratory transmission of the virus, emphasizing the importance of considering multiple sample types for accurate diagnosis and management of the disease. The study also notes that while SARS-CoV-2 RNA was detected in non-respiratory samples, further research is needed to determine the infectious potential of these findings. The research was conducted with ethical approval and informed consent from participants, and the data was analyzed using statistical methods to ensure reliability.

supporting_sources.title: Environmental factors involved in SARS-CoV-2 transmission: effect
supporting_sources.content: The article, published in Environmental Health and Preventive Medicine, explores the environmental factors influencing the transmission of SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, with a focus on indoor environmental quality as a strategy for infection control. The study highlights that SARS-CoV-2 primarily spreads through respiratory droplets in close-contact settings, particularly in enclosed spaces with poor ventilation. The virus can persist on surfaces for up to three days and remains stable in aerosols for several hours, although it is rapidly inactivated by sunlight. The research underscores the importance of controlling indoor environmental quality, particularly ventilation, to mitigate virus transmission. The Japanese Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare has emphasized the "3 Cs"—closed spaces, crowded places, and close-contact settings—as critical factors in preventing COVID-19 clusters. Despite the lack of specific standards for indoor environmental quality control, the study advocates for precautionary measures, including adequate ventilation, filtration, and ultraviolet germicidal irradiation (UVGI), to reduce infection risks. The article calls for further research to better understand the dynamics of SARS-CoV-2 transmission in indoor environments and to develop effective control measures.

supporting_sources.title: 13 Things To Know About Paxlovid, the Latest COVID-19 Pill
supporting_sources.content: The article by Kathy Katella, updated in June 2024, provides an in-depth overview of Paxlovid, an oral antiviral medication developed by Pfizer for treating COVID-19. Initially granted Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) by the FDA in December 2021, Paxlovid received full approval in May 2023 for adults with mild-to-moderate COVID-19 at high risk of severe disease. The medication, available for individuals aged 12 and older, consists of two drugs: nirmatrelvir, which inhibits a key enzyme needed by the virus, and ritonavir, which prolongs nirmatrelvir's effectiveness. Clinical trials demonstrated an 89% reduction in hospitalization and death risk among unvaccinated individuals, prompting the NIH to prioritize it over other treatments. Paxlovid must be taken within five days of symptom onset, with a standard regimen of three pills twice daily for five days. While generally well-tolerated, it can cause side effects like altered taste and diarrhea, and it interacts with various medications, necessitating careful management. The article also addresses the potential for a "rebound" of symptoms post-treatment, which the CDC notes does not indicate resistance or reinfection. Despite its efficacy, Paxlovid is not a substitute for vaccination, and early testing remains crucial for effective treatment. The article emphasizes consulting healthcare providers for personalized medical advice and highlights the ongoing monitoring of Paxlovid's real-world effects.

supporting_sources.title: Science Forum: SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) by the numbers | eLife
supporting_sources.content: The article "Science Forum: SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) by the numbers" provides a comprehensive overview of the key numerical data related to the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which is responsible for the COVID-19 pandemic. It is structured around two main themes: the biology of the virus and the characteristics of infection in a human host. The article compiles data from peer-reviewed literature and uses graphical representations to illustrate the virus's properties, such as its size, genome, and interaction with the human body. It addresses several critical questions, including the rapid spread of the virus, the impact of physical distancing, and the effectiveness of N95 masks. The basic reproduction number (R0) is estimated to be between 2 and 4, indicating the potential for exponential growth in infections without countermeasures. The article also discusses the virus's mutation rate, genome structure, and the stability of virions on surfaces. It highlights the importance of early detection and quarantine due to significant pre-symptomatic transmission. The article emphasizes the need for ongoing research and updates as new data becomes available, providing a valuable resource for understanding the dynamics of the COVID-19 pandemic.

supporting_sources.title: The Plausible Faecal-Oral Transmission Route of Covid-19
supporting_sources.content: The article by Mohammad Khalid Parvez, published in the Journal of Infectious Diseases and Epidemiology, explores the potential faecal-oral transmission route of Covid-19, caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus. The pandemic has significantly impacted global public health, particularly in underdeveloped regions with inadequate healthcare systems. While Covid-19 is primarily spread through direct contact, aerosolized droplets, and fomites, recent studies have detected SARS-CoV-2 RNA in gut specimens and stool samples, indicating a possible faecal-oral transmission route. The article highlights that gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea are present in some Covid-19 patients, and viral RNA has been found in various gastrointestinal and excretory samples. Although viable virus particles have not been consistently isolated from faeces, the presence of viral RNA suggests potential infectivity. The study emphasizes the need for further research to confirm the viability and transmissibility of the virus in water sources, as contaminated water and food could facilitate transmission. The detection of SARS-CoV-2 in wastewater suggests that water surveillance could serve as an early warning system for community spread, especially in areas with poor sanitation. The article calls for more experimental and clinical studies to better understand the role of human excreta in the transmission of Covid-19.

supporting_sources.title: COVID-19 | Johns Hopkins Medicine
supporting_sources.content: The article provides a comprehensive overview of COVID-19, the disease caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which emerged in December 2019. It details the symptoms, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention of the disease. COVID-19 can range from mild to severe, with symptoms such as cough, fever, and shortness of breath, and can lead to serious complications like respiratory failure and organ damage. The virus spreads through droplets and particles in the air, making mask-wearing and hand hygiene crucial for prevention. Diagnosis is primarily through viral tests, including PCR and rapid antigen tests, while antibody tests help determine past exposure. Vaccination is emphasized as the best protection, especially for high-risk groups like the elderly and pregnant women. Treatment varies based on severity, from home care for mild cases to hospitalization for severe ones. The article also highlights the existence of different COVID-19 variants and ongoing research at Johns Hopkins to better understand and combat the virus.

supporting_sources.title: The online competition between pro- and anti-vaccination views
supporting_sources.content: The article published in Nature on May 13, 2020, by Neil F. Johnson and colleagues, explores the complex online dynamics between pro- and anti-vaccination views, particularly in the context of the COVID-19 pandemic. The study maps the interactions of nearly 100 million individuals on Facebook, revealing a highly intricate network of clusters that express varying stances on vaccination. Despite being numerically smaller, anti-vaccination clusters are more central and interconnected with undecided clusters, which are highly active and exhibit significant growth in network links. This dynamic allows anti-vaccination views to spread more effectively than pro-vaccination views, which remain more peripheral. The study employs a theoretical framework that predicts the dominance of anti-vaccination views within a decade if current trends continue. The findings challenge traditional assumptions about undecided individuals and highlight the importance of network cluster dynamics in shaping public opinion. The research suggests that targeted interventions at the cluster level could help counter the spread of anti-vaccination narratives, offering insights that could also apply to other contentious issues like climate change.

supporting_sources.title: The battleground of COVID-19 vaccine misinformation on Facebook
supporting_sources.content: The study, conducted by researchers from various universities, investigates the dynamics of COVID-19 vaccine misinformation on Facebook, focusing on the interaction between misinformation spreaders and fact checkers from March 1, 2020, to March 1, 2021. Utilizing social network analysis and ANOVA tests, the study analyzed English-language posts from public Facebook accounts, revealing that 46.6% of posts contained misinformation, while 47.4% were fact-checking posts. Among the fact-checking posts, 28.5% repeated the original misinformation, which garnered more comments than those that did not. The study found that misinformation spreaders occupied more central positions in the URL co-sharing network, indicating their strategic coordination in spreading false information. In contrast, fact checkers were less coordinated and often occupied peripheral network positions. The research highlights the importance of strategic network positioning for fact checkers to effectively combat misinformation. It also suggests that repeating misinformation in fact-checking posts can enhance user engagement, although it may risk reinforcing the false claims. The study underscores the need for social media platforms and public health authorities to continue proactive fact-checking efforts and improve network strategies to counter misinformation effectively.

supporting_sources.title: The online competition between pro- and anti-vaccination views
supporting_sources.content: The article examines the online competition between pro- and anti-vaccination views, particularly in the context of a potential future vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19. It highlights the dangers of distrust in scientific expertise, which can lead to amplified outbreaks, as seen with measles in 2019. The study maps the complex landscape of vaccine contention among approximately three billion Facebook users, identifying nearly 100 million individuals in dynamic, interconnected clusters across various regions and languages. Despite being smaller, anti-vaccination clusters are highly entangled with undecided clusters, while pro-vaccination clusters remain more peripheral. The theoretical framework used in the study replicates the rapid growth of anti-vaccination views and predicts their dominance within a decade. These insights challenge conventional views on undecided individuals in health-related debates and emphasize the importance of network cluster dynamics, offering guidance for developing policies to counteract the shift towards negative views on vaccination.

supporting_sources.title: The Anti-vaxxers Are Winning the Battle on Facebook - Newsweek
supporting_sources.content: The article by Jason Murdock in Newsweek discusses a study led by Neil Johnson from George Washington University, which reveals that anti-vaccination groups on Facebook are more effective at attracting undecided users compared to pro-vaccination communities. The study analyzed Facebook communities with nearly 100 million users, categorizing them into clusters to understand their interactions and influence. Contrary to expectations, the research found that anti-vax groups, though smaller, are more agile and have become deeply intertwined with larger undecided groups, referred to as "Green," while pro-vaccination groups, or "Blue," are less effective in engaging these users. The study warns that if current trends continue, anti-vaccination support could dominate in about a decade. The anti-vax groups offer diverse narratives that appeal to various concerns, such as skepticism towards big pharma and government, whereas pro-vaccination messages are perceived as monotonous. The research, published in Nature, highlights the importance of targeting undecided individuals to prevent a shift away from herd immunity, especially in the context of COVID-19. The study's data, collected before the pandemic, also noted significant growth in anti-vax clusters during measles outbreaks, with some increasing by over 300%, while pro-vaccine clusters grew by less than 100%. The findings underscore the need for pro-vaccination efforts to focus on engaging undecided users rather than confronting entrenched anti-vax groups.

supporting_sources.title: Using Machine Learning to Compare Provaccine and Antivaccine
supporting_sources.content: The study, published in JMIR Public Health and Surveillance, investigates the differences in discourse between provaccine and antivaccine advocates on social media, specifically Twitter, using machine learning algorithms. The researchers aimed to understand how these groups engage and persuade the public regarding immunization. They collected 39,962 tweets and developed a supervised classification algorithm to categorize them into provaccine, antivaccine, and neutral categories. An unsupervised clustering algorithm was then used to identify prominent topics, and a qualitative content analysis was conducted to explore how these topics frame vaccines using Entman’s four framing dimensions. The study found that antivaccine topics exhibit greater intertopic distinctiveness than provaccine topics, which contributes to higher engagement levels. Antivaccine advocates effectively use all four persuasive message frames, while provaccine advocates often lack a clear problem statement. These findings suggest that the distinctiveness and comprehensive framing of antivaccine content contribute to its influence, highlighting the need for provaccine content to develop clearer problem statements to counteract the negative impact on vaccine uptake rates.
